column4: lit: Steel) is a city in Moscow Oblast
column6: located 58 kilometers (36 mi) east of Moscow.  Population: 155
column13: 000 (1939). It was previously known as Zatishye (until 1928).

column1: It was known as Zatishye (Зати́шье) until 1928. In 1938
Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: it is incorporated as Elektrostal City Under Oblast Jurisdiction—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column3: Elektrostal City Under Oblast Jurisdiction is incorporated as Elektrostal Urban Okrug.

column1: Elektrostal is a center of metallurgy and heavy machinery manufacturing. Major companies include:

column2: JSC is a designer and manufacturer of equipment for producing seamless hot-rolled
column3: cold-rolled and welded steel materials and metallurgical equipment.
Russia's largest producer of fuel rod assemblies for nuclear power plants
column4: which are exported to many countries in Europe.

column1: The Powerline Ekibastuz-Kokshetau connects Elektrostal to the GRES-2 Power Station in Ekibastuz.  The power-line was designed for 1150 kV but currently only operates at 400 kV over the section Kokshetau—Elektrostal.The 9th radio center in Elektrostal is home to a high power medium wave transmitter.
The first S-400 Triumf missile defense system was deployed at Elektrostal
Elektrostal is linked by Elektrichka suburban electric trains to Moscow's Kursky Rail Terminal with a travel time of 1 hour and 20 minutes. Long distance buses link Elektrostal to Noginsk
column2: Moscow and other nearby towns. Local public transport includes buses.

column1: The city ice hockey team Kristall Elektrostal was established in 1949 and plays in the Junior Hockey League Division B.
